title: Step 1 – Introduction to Next.js
content:
Welcome to the **Next.js 14 Fundamentals Course**!

Next.js is a powerful **React framework** created by **Vercel**. It helps developers build fast, scalable, and SEO-friendly applications using modern web standards. This module will explain *why* Next.js is important, *how* it works, and *what* makes it different from traditional React.
explain: Next.js builds upon React, adding routing, rendering, and performance optimizations out of the box.

quiz.question: Who created and maintains the Next.js framework?

title: Step 2 – Setup Environment
content:
Before building with Next.js, make sure your environment is ready:

1️⃣ Install **Node.js v18+ (LTS)** from [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org)
2️⃣ Use **VS Code** as your editor
3️⃣ Verify your versions:
explain: Next.js requires Node.js version 18 or higher. npm (included with Node.js) is used to install dependencies.

quiz.question: Which command verifies your Node.js version?

title: Step 3 – Create a Next.js Project
content: To initialize a new Next.js app, run the following command in your terminal:
code:
npx create-next-app@latest next-theory --typescript --app
cd next-theory
npm run dev
explain: The command creates a complete TypeScript-based Next.js project with the App Router enabled. Open http://localhost:3000 to view your running app.

quiz.question: What flag enables the App Router when creating a Next.js app?

title: Step 4 – Explore the Project Structure
content: After project creation, your folder structure should look like this:
code:
app/
  layout.tsx
  page.tsx
  globals.css
public/
  favicon.ico
components/
  Header.tsx
package.json
explain: The **app/** folder defines your routes and layouts. Every folder with a `page.tsx` file becomes a route automatically.

quiz.question: Which folder defines routes in the App Router?

title: Step 5 – Understanding Rendering Modes
content:
Next.js provides several rendering strategies depending on your needs:

1️⃣ **SSR (Server-Side Rendering):** Content is rendered for each request.

2️⃣ **SSG (Static Site Generation):** Pages are built once during build time.

3️⃣ **ISR (Incremental Static Regeneration):** Static pages are rebuilt in the background.

4️⃣ **CSR (Client-Side Rendering):** Traditional React rendering inside the browser.

quiz.question: Which rendering mode generates HTML on every request?

title: Step 6 – Server vs Client Components
content:
Next.js 13+ introduces **Server Components** (default) and **Client Components** (interactive).

A **Server Component** runs on the server and doesn’t include client-side JavaScript. A **Client Component** must declare `'use client'` at the top to use hooks and events.
explain: The `'use client'` directive makes this component interactive and able to use React hooks.

quiz.question: What directive enables interactivity in a component?

title: Step 7 – File-Based Routing Example
content: Next.js automatically creates routes from files inside the `app/` directory. Here’s how to create static and dynamic routes:
code:
app/
  page.tsx          // Home page → '/'
  about/page.tsx    // About page → '/about'
  blog/[id]/page.tsx // Dynamic route → '/blog/:id'
explain: Each folder with a `page.tsx` becomes a route. Dynamic segments like `[id]` capture URL parameters automatically.

quiz.question: What folder naming syntax defines a dynamic route?

title: Step 11 – Reflection and Start Workshop
content:
Congratulations! You now understand the **core concepts of Next.js** — rendering, routing, components, data fetching, and optimization.

Now it's time to apply your knowledge in practice.

➡️ Proceed to the **Next.js Workshop** and start building your own project step by step.
